docs.lead_paragraph: A single, concentrated dose of radiation may be as effective as six straight weeks of daily radiation treatment for women who have had a cancerous lump removed from a breast, preliminary research suggests. The experimental treatment could make lumpectomy -- a breast-saving type of cancer surgery in which only the lump and some surrounding tissue are removed -- available to many more women.

headline.main: Briefer Regimen May Fight Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Preliminary research suggests that single, concentrated dose of radiation may be as effective as six straight weeks of daily radiation treatment for women who have had cancerous lump removed from breast; many women who are candidates for lumpectomy decide against it because they cannot spend six weeks receiving daily radiation treatment that typically follows (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two recent studies offer new evidence that when it comes to fighting heart disease, a patient's state of mind can play an important role. Addressing a recent American Heart Association conference in Anaheim, Calif., researchers said a positive attitude was not only associated with better outcomes for heart attack patients, but might even stave off heart disease.

headline.main: In Heart Disease, Head Can Be an Ally

docs.abstract: Studies offer new evidence that having positive outlook reduces vulnerability to heart problems and increases prospects for successful recovery from bypass surgery; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A single night on call can impair a surgeon's steadiness of hand, leading to possibly serious mistakes, a new study reports. In the current British Medical Journal, researchers cited evidence that fatigue from being on call led surgeons to operate more slowly when using a device that simulates surgery and to make unnecessary movements and even mistakes.

headline.main: Surgeons Need Steady Hand, and Sleep

docs.abstract: Study finds that single night on call can impair surgeon's steadiness of hand, leading to possible serious mistakes; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For many people who have had coronary artery bypass surgery, regaining emotional strength is a tougher challenge than recuperating physically. Traditionally, rehabilitation specialists working with bypass patients have focused on rebuilding weakened muscles after surgery. But recently, a few teams of cardiac specialists -- nurses, doctors and psychologists -- have begun to concentrate on the mental fatigue and overwhelming sadness that strike many patients.

headline.main: Facing Up to Depression After a Bypass

docs.abstract: Six people describe depression they experienced after undergoing coronary bypass operations; estimates on incidence of depression after bypass surgery vary widely from fewer than a third of patients to more than three-quarters; photos (L)
docs.snippet: For many people who have had coronary artery bypass surgery, regaining emotional strength is a tougher challenge than recuperating physically.     Traditionally, rehabilitation specialists working with bypass patients have focused on rebuilding...

docs.lead_paragraph: Scholars have spent centuries trying to understand the doctor-patient relationship, and they have not gotten very far at all. Is it a friendship, a partnership or just a fee-for-service arrangement? Are the parties peers, or more like parent and child, or priest and parishioner (or sergeant and grunt)? Might ''necessary evil'' be the phrase each would secretly pick for the other? After several millennia, the model is still under construction. Perhaps the experts should turn to the tools of modern biology for help.

headline.main: Learning to Care for Patients, in Truest Sense

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger column says Dr Orit Beitner, Manhattan gynecologist, has come to new understanding of doctor-patient relationship after a patient of hers of 12 years standing died in World Trade Center attacks; Beitner is sorry not to have told this patient how much she meant to her and is beginning to let other patients know her feelings for them (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two recent reports at a tropical disease conference focused on malaria, which kills 1.5 million to 2.7 million people a year. In the first report, researchers said they had discovered that compounds in garlic known as disulfides could fight both malaria and cancer. Experts have suspected for years that disulfides, also found in onions, might fight malaria, and disulfides have been shown effective in animals. Ian E. Crandall of the University of Toronto, who presented the study, said he wanted to improve the understanding of how disulfides work.

headline.main: Keeping Malaria at Bay, With Garlic

docs.abstract: Study finds that compounds in garlic known as disufides can fight both malaria and cancer; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention devises simple way to detect counterfeit malaria drugs from real thing (S)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Besides the obvious perils, hazards for long-distance space travelers may also lurk within their own bodies. A new study reports that space travel appears to lend vigor to viruses that lie dormant in many people. Under normal circumstances, the body can fight off these viruses -- including the ones that cause herpes and chickenpox -- with little effort. But with space travel, it appears, things may change.

headline.main: Off to Mars, Then to the Drugstore

docs.abstract: Study with Epstein-Barr virus suggests that space travel can lend vigor to viruses that lie dormant in many people (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At least 12 million people in this country have a condition affecting their limbs that could give even the calmest among them the heebie-jeebies. It goes by the exceedingly apt name of restless legs syndrome and is characterized by a variety of discomforting sensations that occur at rest and compel sufferers to get up and move around. People describe the sensations as creeping, tingling, pulling, twitching, tearing, aching, throbbing, prickling or grabbing; some feel as if insects are crawling on them or an electric current is running through their limbs. Some even use the word painful. But whatever the nature of the sensation, the result is the same: an uncontrollable urge to relieve it by moving the affected limb.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on restless legs syndrome, which affects some 12 million Americans, causing them variety of discomforting sensations when sitting or lying still for any length of time and compelling them to get up and move around; discusses causes and treatments; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One might expect that smokers who decide to have themselves checked for lung cancer with a CAT scan must also be giving some serious thought to giving up cigarettes. A new study suggests that this may be the case -- and urges the doctors who conduct the scans to accompany them with advice to patients about ways to quit smoking.

headline.main: Help for Those Willing to Kick a Habit

docs.abstract: Study suggests that almost quarter of smokers who are checked for lung cancer with CAT scan may give up smoking within six months of scan (S)
